revision.text:
{{Redirect|Dr. Phil|his television show|Dr. Phil (talk show)|the British comedian|Phil Hammond|the academic degree|Doctor of Philosophy}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Lead too short|date=September 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2013}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}}{{Infobox person | name = Phil McGraw | image = Phil_1.jpg | caption = Phil McGraw photographed by [[Jerry Avenaim]] for the cover of ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine, 2001 | birth_name = Phillip Calvin McGraw | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1950|9|1}} | birth_place = [[Vinita, Oklahoma]], U.S. | residence = [[Beverly Hills, California]], U.S. | alma_mater = {{unbulleted list|[[Midwestern State University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
|[[University of North Texas]] {{small|([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]])}}
}} | occupation = [[Television presenter|Television host]] | salary = $79 million (2017){{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maddieberg/2017/11/07/the-worlds-highest-paid-tv-hosts-dr-phil-ellen-degeneres-and-ryan-seacrest-lead/#229fd7125bf6 | work=Forbes | title=The World's Highest-Paid TV Hosts: Dr. Phil, Ellen DeGeneres And Ryan Seacrest Lead | date=July 25, 2018}} | networth = | spouse = {{unbulleted list|{{marriage|Debbie Higgins McCall|1970|1973|end=annulled}}|{{marriage|Robin Jameson|1976}}}} | children = {{unbulleted list|[[Jay McGraw|Jay]] {{font|size=95%|text=(born 1979)}}|{{font|size=95%|text=Jordan (born 1986)}}}} | website = {{URL|drphil.com}} }} '''Phillip Calvin McGraw''' (born September 1, 1950),{{cite web| url= http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/phil-mcgraw/bio/233566/ | title= Phil McGraw| publisher= [[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] |accessdate= April 27, 2015}} known as '''Dr. Phil''', is an American television personality, author, [[psychologist]], and the host of the television show ''[[Dr. Phil (talk show)|Dr. Phil]]'', which debuted in 2002. McGraw first gained celebrity status with appearances on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' in the late 1990s.{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=980DE4DA1131F934A15753C1A9659C8B63| title=Dr. Phil, Medicine Man | last=Day|first= Sherri|work=The New York Times|accessdate=October 23, 2006 | date=October 27, 2003}} In 2017, ''Forbes'' listed his earnings at $79 million for the previous 12 months, and ranked him the 15th highest earning celebrity in the world.{{cite news|title=The World's Highest-Paid Celebrities|url=https://www.forbes.com/celebrities/list/#tab:overall|agency=Forbes|date=November 15, 2017}} ==Early life== McGraw was born in [[Vinita, Oklahoma|Vinita]], Oklahoma, the son of Anne Geraldine "Jerry" (née Stevens) and Joseph J. "Joe" McGraw, Jr.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesrecordnews.com/news/2011/jun/19/geraldine-jerrie-mcgraw/|title=Geraldine "Jerrie" McGraw|first=Times Record|last=News|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061242/http://www.timesrecordnews.com/news/2011/jun/19/geraldine-jerrie-mcgraw/|archivedate=September 21, 2013|df=mdy-all}} He grew up with two older sisters, Deana and Donna, and younger sister Brenda{{cite web | author=|url=http://drphil.com/shows/show/64 | title=Birth Order: Dr. Phil's Sisters Talk |year=2002|publisher=Peteski Productions, Inc.| accessdate=January 14, 2008}} in the oilfields of [[North Texas]] where his father was an equipment supplier. During McGraw's childhood, his family moved so his father could pursue a lifelong goal of becoming a [[psychologist]]. McGraw attended [[Shawnee Mission North High School]] in [[Overland Park, Kansas|Overland Park]], Kansas. In 1968, he was awarded a football scholarship to the [[University of Tulsa]], where he played middle linebacker under Coach [[Glenn Dobbs]]. On November 23 of that year, McGraw's team lost to the [[Houston Cougars football|University of Houston]] 100–6, which is one of the most lopsided games in college football history.{{cite web | author=University of Tulsa|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/tuls/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/2007FBrecords.pdf | title=2007 Golden Hurricane Football Media Guide |publisher=[[University of Tulsa]]| accessdate=January 7, 2008|format=PDF}} Coach Dobbs retired after that season and McGraw transferred to [[Midwestern State University]] in [[Wichita Falls, Texas|Wichita Falls]], Texas. ==Education and early career== McGraw graduated in 1975 from [[Midwestern State University]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[psychology]]. He went on to earn an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in [[experimental psychology]] in 1976, and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] degree in [[clinical psychology]] in 1979 at the [[University of North Texas]],{{cite web | author=|url=http://www.unt.edu/northtexan/archives/s06/alumniawards.htm | title=University of North Texas North Texan Online Summer 2006: Honored Alumni |publisher=[[University of North Texas]]| accessdate=January 7, 2008}} where his [[dissertation]] was titled "Rheumatoid Arthritis: A Psychological Intervention".[https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc331903/m1/1/"] "Rheumatoid Arthritis: A Psychological Intervention"[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=+%22Rheumatoid+Arthritis%3A+A+Psychological+Intervention.%22&hl=en&btnG=Search&as_sdt=80001&as_sdtp=on "Rheumatoid Arthritis: A Psychological Intervention"] Scholar.Google.com McGraw was guided through the doctoral program by Frank Lawlis, who later became the primary contributing psychologist for the ''Dr. Phil'' television show.{{cite web|url=http://www.franklawlis.com/bio.htm |title=Frank Lawlis BIO |accessdate=January 22, 2009 |publisher=Dr. Frank Lawlis |year=2009 |author=Anon |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210121754/http://www.franklawlis.com/bio.htm |archivedate=December 10, 2008 }} After obtaining his doctorate, McGraw joined his father, Joe McGraw, in Wichita Falls, Texas, where the elder McGraw had established his private psychology practice.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/65557|title=Paging Doctor Phil|accessdate=January 13, 2008|publisher=Newsweek|year=2002|author=Marc Peyser}} In 1983, McGraw and his father joined Thelma Box, a successful Texas businesswoman, in presenting "Pathways" seminars, "experience-based training which allows individuals to achieve and create their own results."{{cite web|url=http://gopathways.org/about_pathways.htm |title=About Pathways |accessdate=September 29, 2008 |publisher=Pathways Core Training |year=2007 |author=Pathways Core Training |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704075333/http://www.gopathways.org/about_pathways.htm |archivedate=July 4, 2008 }} Critics claim that many of the "phrases and the terminology and the quaint sayings" used by McGraw on the ''Oprah'' and ''Dr. Phil'' shows were coined by Box and presented by McGraw in this seminar. McGraw admits that some of the material from ''Life Strategies'', his first best-seller, is taken directly from the Pathways seminar. However, he has never mentioned Box or her contributions to his success in any of his books or TV shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2000-04-13/news/analyze-this/full|title=Analyze This|accessdate=January 13, 2008|publisher=Dallas Observer|year=2000|author=Mark Donald}} Eight years after joining Box, McGraw signed an agreement for the sale of his Pathways seminar stock for $325,000 without notifying either his father or Box of the impending sale. Box founded her own seminars entitled "Choices."{{cite web|url=http://www.choicesseminars.com/About.php |title=About Thelma Box |accessdate=January 13, 2008 |publisher=Choices Seminars |year=2007 |author=Choices Seminars |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207091147/http://choicesseminars.com/About.php |archivedate=February 7, 2009 }} === Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists === On October 21, 1988, the Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists determined that McGraw had hired a former patient for "part-time temporary employment".{{cite web|url=http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3496/3743288391_cfa3a1c50b_b.jpg|title=The Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists Finding of Facts, page 2}} Specifically, the board cited "a possible failure to provide proper separation between termination of therapy and the initiation of employment,"{{cite web|url=http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2469/3744083552_38d45c8043_b.jpg|title=The Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists Finding of Facts, page 1}} issued a letter of reprimand and imposed administrative penalties.{{cite web|url=http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2454/3744080578_26c0e60fae_b.jpg|title=The Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists Conclusions of Law, page 3}} The board also investigated claims made by the patient of inappropriate contact initiated by McGraw, but the "Findings of Fact" document issued by the board on October 21, 1988, at the end of its investigation includes no reference to any physical contact of any kind. It specifically identified "the therapeutic and business relationships" as constituting McGraw's sole issue with the board. McGraw fulfilled all terms of the board's requirements, and the board closed its complaint file in June 1990.{{cite web|url=http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3516/3743291121_f47f5434f6_b.jpg|title=The Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists Letter, page 1}} ===Courtroom Sciences, Inc=== In 1990, McGraw joined lawyer Gary Dobbs in co-founding Courtroom Sciences, Inc. (CSI), a [[trial consulting]] firm through which McGraw later came into contact with [[Oprah Winfrey]].{{cite web |url=http://ecpa.cpa.state.tx.us/coa/servlet/cpa.app.coa.CoaGetTp?Pg=tpid&Search_Nm=Courtroom%20Sciences%20&Button=search&Search_ID=17523143273 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213215546/http://ecpa.cpa.state.tx.us/coa/servlet/cpa.app.coa.CoaGetTp?Pg=tpid&Search_Nm=Courtroom%20Sciences%20&Button=search&Search_ID=17523143273 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 13, 2008 |title=Franchise Tax Certification of Account Status |accessdate=January 7, 2008 |publisher=Texas Comptroller |year=2008 |author=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts |df=mdy }} Eventually, CSI became a profitable enterprise, advising [[Fortune 500]] companies and injured plaintiffs in achieving settlements. McGraw is no longer an officer or director of the company. After starting CSI, McGraw ceased the practice of psychology. He kept his license current and in good standing until he elected to retire it 15 years later in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3468/3750482552_6024990f7b_b.jpg|title=Dr. Phil's License Status|author=Texas State Board of Examiners of Psychologists}} Appearing on the ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today Show]]'' in January 2008, McGraw said that he has made it "very clear" that his current work does not involve the practice of psychology. He also said that he had "retired from psychology".{{cite news|last1=Considine|first1=Bob|title=Dr. Phil defends intentions with Britney Spears|url=http://www.today.com/id/22901694#.V9nbOdMrKV4|work=Today|date=1 February 2008|quote=In 2002, the California Board of Psychology determined that McGraw did not need his license for the purposes of his show because he was “doing more entertainment than psychology.”}} According to the ''Today Show'', the California Board of Psychology determined in 2002 that he did not require a license because his show involves "entertainment" rather than psychology. The TV show ''[[Bull (2016 TV Series)|Bull]]'' is based on his experience as a trial consultant, and he is credited as one of the creators of the series.{{fact|date=June 2018}} ==Television career== ===Oprah Winfrey and the ''Dr. Phil'' show=== In 1995, [[Oprah Winfrey]] hired McGraw's legal consulting firm CSI to prepare her for the [[Food libel laws|Amarillo Texas beef trial]]. Winfrey was so impressed with McGraw that she thanked him for her victory in that case, which ended in 1998. Soon after, she invited him to appear on her show. His appearance proved so successful that he began appearing weekly as a relationship and life strategy expert on Tuesdays starting in April 1998. The next year, McGraw published his first best-selling book, ''Life Strategies''. In the next four years, McGraw published three additional best-selling relationship books, along with workbooks to complement them. As of September 2002, McGraw formed Peteski Productions{{cite web|url=http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/corpdata/ShowAllList?QueryCorpNumber=C2468059|title=Peteski Productions, Inc.|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=State of California|year=2008|author=Secretary of State|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212091755/http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/corpdata/ShowAllList?QueryCorpNumber=C2468059|archivedate=February 12, 2008|df=mdy-all}} and launched his own [[TV syndication|syndicated]] daily television show, ''[[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]]'', produced by Winfrey's [[Harpo Productions|Harpo Studios]]. The format is an advice show, where he tackles a different topic on each show, offering advice for his guests' troubles. ===Weight loss products=== In 2003, McGraw entered the weight loss business, selling shakes, energy bars, and supplements. These products were promoted on his show with his sisters Deana and Brenda and nephew Tony among the featured testimonials on the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.drphil.com/shows/show/267|title= Weight Loss Challenge: Dr. Phil's Family|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Peteski Productions, Inc.|year=2004|author=Anon}} These products' labels, which carried the brand name "Shape It Up, Woo, Woo!", stated: "These products contain scientifically researched levels of ingredients that can help you change your behavior to take control of your weight." This met with swift criticism from various sources, accusing McGraw (a clinical psychologist, and not a physician) of lacking the expertise to recommend weight loss products. Facing a [[Federal Trade Commission]] investigation into Shape Up's claims, McGraw pulled his supplements off the market in March 2004, and the FTC dropped its probe. In October 2005, several people who used McGraw's products declared an intent to file a [[class action lawsuit]] against him, claiming that although the supplements cost $120 per month they did not stimulate weight loss.{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20051007/drphil_classaction_051007/20051007/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051013055352/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20051007/drphil_classaction_051007/20051007 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 13, 2005 |title=Class-action status sought in Dr. Phil diet suit |accessdate=October 21, 2007 |publisher=CTV Globe Media |year=2005 |author=CTV.ca News Staff |df=mdy-all }} McGraw settled the suit in September 2006 for $10.5 million.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-09-26-dr-phil-diet_x.htm|title=Settlement reached on Dr. Phil diet plan|accessdate=October 21, 2007|publisher=[[USA Today]] – [[Associated Press]]|agency=Associated Press | date=September 26, 2006}} Some of the settlement ($6 million) may be paid to the plaintiffs in the form of [[Amway]] ([[Quixtar]]) brand [[Nutrilite]] vitamins.{{cite web|url=http://www.metrotimes.com/%5Ceditorial%5Cstory.asp?id=9791 |title=Slimming the Amway |accessdate=October 21, 2007 |publisher=Metro Times |year=2006 |author=Metro Times News Hits staff |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010082818/http://www.metrotimes.com/editorial/story.asp?id=9791 |archivedate=October 10, 2007 }} === ''The Making of Dr. Phil'' unauthorized biography (2003) === ''The Making of Dr. Phil'' is a biography by Sophia Dembling, a reporter from ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'', and Lisa Gutierrez, a reporter from ''[[The Kansas City Star]]''.{{cite book |last= Dembling|first= Sophia|title= The Making of Dr. Phil: The Straight-Talking True Story of Everyone's Favorite Therapist|year= 2005|publisher= Wiley|isbn= 0-471-69659-5}} The book probes McGraw's history, with interviews of his childhood friends and former classmates. The book reports that McGraw allegedly used unethical business practices in a gym business early in his career, that he was allegedly abusive to his first wife and to his staff, while noting that he overcame adversity through setting goals and was persistent in achieving success. The book received no promotional help from McGraw or his associates.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/articles/cache/a1938.asp|title=Battling Dr. Phil|accessdate=October 21, 2007|publisher=Media Bistro – Jupitermedia Corporation|year=2004|author=Sophia Dembling}} In 2005, McGraw published another best-selling book, ''Family First'', along with a workbook. He also signed a five-year extension of his syndication deal with his show's distributors, [[King World Productions]], Inc. The deal will pay McGraw $15 million a year{{cite web|url=http://www.riehlworldview.com/carnivorous_conservative/2005/09/for_the_dr_phil.html|title=For The Dr. Phil Fans|accessdate=January 22, 2008|publisher=NY Post|year=2005|author=Riehl World (quoting NY Post)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080210161112/http://www.riehlworldview.com/carnivorous_conservative/2005/09/for_the_dr_phil.html|archivedate=February 10, 2008|df=mdy-all}} and keep the show in production through the 2013–2014 television season.{{cite web|url=http://www.kingworld.com/PressRelease.aspx?pressReleaseID=192 |title=Dr. Phil Signs on for Five More Years |accessdate=January 22, 2008 |publisher=King World |year=2005 |author=Anon |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213162534/http://www.kingworld.com/PressRelease.aspx?pressReleaseID=192 |archivedate=February 13, 2008 }} ===Spin-off shows=== Also in 2005, McGraw's son Jay's television show ''[[Renovate My Family]]'' (a clone of ABC's ''[[Extreme Makeover: Home Edition]]'') was canceled at the start of its second season following a renovated family's lawsuit.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/renovate-my-family/show/28832/story/476.html|title=Renovated family sues|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Media Life|year=2005|author=Colin Mahan}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/tracking/viewer.html?tid=15096&ref_id=28832&ref_type=101|title=Wrecker's ball for 'Renovate My Family'|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Media Life|year=2005|author=CNET Networks Entertainment|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211035445/http://www.tv.com/tracking/viewer.html?tid=15096&ref_id=28832&ref_type=101|archivedate=December 11, 2008|df=mdy-all}} Jay McGraw and Phil McGraw then formed [[Stage 29 Productions]].{{cite web|url=http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/corpdata/ShowAllList?QueryCorpNumber=C2786543|title=Stage 29 Media Productions, Inc.|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=State of California|year=2008|author=Secretary of State|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212091800/http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/corpdata/ShowAllList?QueryCorpNumber=C2786543|archivedate=February 12, 2008|df=mdy-all}} A week later, McGraw and son announced a new show called ''Moochers'' (a clone of ABC's ''Kicked Out'');{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2005/scene/markets-festivals/dr-phil-takes-on-moochers-1117934039/|title=Dr. Phil takes on 'Moochers'|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Variety|author=Josef Adalian | date=December 5, 2005}} however, the show was canceled before any episodes aired. McGraw also released another book, ''Love Smart'', which did not achieve the success of his previous bestsellers. In 2006, the ''Dr. Phil House'' (a clone of CBS's ''[[Big Brother (TV series)|Big Brother]]'') began airing as part of the ''Dr. Phil'' television show. Following a protest by neighbors, the house in Los Angeles was shut down, and production resumed on a sound stage on a studio back lot.{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2006/10/10/dr-phil-house-shut-down-by-angry-residents/|title="Dr. Phil" House Shut Down By Angry Residents|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=TMZ Productions, Inc.|year=2006|author=TMZ Staff}} McGraw reached the number 22 spot on the [[Forbes Celebrity 100]] list, with income of $45 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/53/1VDD.html|title=2006 Forbes Celebrity 100|accessdate=February 2, 2008|publisher=Forbes|year=2006|author=Anon}} Another Stage 29 show, ''[[Decision House]]'' (a remix of the ''Dr. Phil House'') aired from September through November 2007 but was canceled due to poor reviews and dismal ratings.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/12/arts/television/12bell.html|title=The Marriage Is in Trouble, So They Take It Onto Television|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=The New York Times|author=Ginia Bellafante | date=September 12, 2007}} Ratings for the ''Dr. Phil'' show in 2007 began to slide. In May, viewership was close to 7 million people.{{cite web|url=http://www.nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |title=Week of May 21, 2007|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Nielsen|year=2007|author=Nielsen TV |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070609071308/http://www.nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |archivedate = June 9, 2007}} However, by year's end, viewership was about 5.5 million people (#10 for syndicated TV shows, and just under ''[[Everybody Loves Raymond]]'', ''[[Family Guy]]'' and ''[[CSI: Miami]]'').{{cite web|url=http://www.nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |title=Week of December 31, 2007 |accessdate=January 17, 2008 |publisher=Nielsen |year=2008 |author=Nielsen TV |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103194316/http://www.nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |archivedate=January 3, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} By August 2008, viewership slipped to just over 4 million people.{{cite web|url=http://nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |title=Week of August 11, 2008 |accessdate=August 26, 2008 |publisher=Nielsen |year=2008 |author=Nielsen TV |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609052433/http://www.nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |archivedate=June 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Two weeks later, the show slipped beneath the Nielsen top 12 syndicated TV shows, and has since resurfaced.{{cite web|url=http://nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |title=Week of August 25, 2008 |accessdate=September 18, 2008 |publisher=Nielsen |year=2008 |author=Nielsen TV |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609052433/http://www.nielsen.com/media/toptens_television.html |archivedate=June 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} McGraw's income fell by 1/3 to $30 million, and he dropped to the number 30 spot on the Forbes Celebrity 100 list.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/53/07celebrities_Dr-Phil-McGraw_1VDD.html|title=2007 Forbes Celebrity 100|accessdate=February 2, 2008|publisher=Forbes|author=Lea Goldman, Monte Burke and Kiri Blakeley|date=June 14, 2007}} Late in 2007, McGraw began promoting his 2008 ''Dr. Phil Show'' extension, ''[[The Doctors (2008 TV series)|The Doctors]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117974640.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |title='Dr. Phil' spinoff sent to market |accessdate=January 12, 2008 |publisher=Variety |author=John Dempsey |date=October 24, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031235731/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117974640.html?categoryid=14&cs=1 |archivedate=October 31, 2007 }} The show is hosted by television personality and ER physician [[Travis Lane Stork|Travis Stork]] (''The Bachelor''). Other experts scheduled to appear include various personalities who have appeared on the ''Dr. Phil'' show over the years, such as Lisa Masterson, an [[obstetrician]]/[[gynecologist]]; [[Andrew P. Ordon|Andrew Ordon]], a [[plastic surgeon]]; and Jim Sears, a [[pediatrician]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thedoctorstv.com/main/the_doctors_section_head|title=Meet Our Doctors|accessdate=September 30, 2008|publisher=Stage 29, LLC|year=2008|author=Anon.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120914142245/http://www.thedoctorstv.com/main/the_doctors_section_head|archivedate=September 14, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Masterson, Ordon, and Sears appeared on the ''Dr. Phil'' show during the 2007–08 season so that McGraw could instruct them on "how to give articulate medical advice while being scrutinized by a studio audience in Los Angeles."{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} McGraw's eldest son, Jay McGraw, is executive producer of the show. ''The Doctors'' debuted on September 8, 2008, and, as of November 10, 2008, had a 2.0 rating.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?date=11/11/08&id=20081111cbs02 |title=Breaking News – The Doctors Hits its Highest Ratings Yet |publisher=TheFutonCritic.com |date=November 11, 2008 |accessdate=December 31, 2010}} === Kalpoe lawsuit (2006) === McGraw was named a co-defendant, along with [[CBS]] Television, in a 2006 lawsuit filed in relation to the disappearance of [[Natalee Holloway]].{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,236558,00.html|title=Wrongful death, Defamation lawsuits filed in Natalee Halloway case|accessdate=October 21, 2007|publisher=FOX News|author=FOX News | date=December 15, 2006}} The lawsuit was filed by [[Deepak Kalpoe]] and his brother [[Satish Kalpoe]], who claimed that an interview they did with McGraw, aired in September 2005, was "manipulated and later broadcast as being accurate, and which portrays Deepak Kalpoe and Satish Kalpoe 'as engaging in criminal activity against Natalee Holloway and constitutes defamation.'" The Kalpoe brothers claimed invasion of privacy, fraud, deceit, defamation, emotional distress, and civil conspiracy in the suit, which was filed in the Los Angeles Superior Court.{{Cite web|title = Surinamese Brothers Sue Dr. Phil As Halloway Parents Sue Back {{!}} Caribbean360|url = http://www.caribbean360.com/news/surinamese-brothers-sue-dr-phil-as-halloway-parents-sue-back|accessdate = 2015-09-21}}{{cite web|url=http://homepage.mac.com/mcgraw.kalpoe.docs/kalpoe.mcgraw.index.html|title=Pleading Index: Kalpoe v. McGraw|accessdate=October 21, 2007|publisher=Apple Inc.|year=2007|author=Unknown|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112085810/http://homepage.mac.com/mcgraw.kalpoe.docs/kalpoe.mcgraw.index.html|archivedate=November 12, 2007|df=mdy-all}} On March 17, 2015, the lawsuit against McGraw and CBS was dismissed.{{cite web|title=READ THE BOMBSHELL DISMISSAL|url=http://radaronline.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Mcgraw-signed.pdf/|publisher=Radar Online, LLC|accessdate=21 April 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004055338/http://radaronline.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Mcgraw-signed.pdf/|archivedate=October 4, 2015|pages=1–4|date=17 March 2015|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} The court records disclosed the lawsuit by Deepak and Satish Kalpoe was rejected one week before the civil trial was set to begin.{{cite news|title=Lawsuit against Dr. Phil in Natalee Holloway case dismissed|url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2015/04/lawsuit_against_dr_phil_in_nat.html|accessdate=21 April 2017|work=Associated Press|publisher=Alabama Media Group|date=15 April 2015}}{{cite news|title=Victory For Dr. Phil! Defamation Lawsuit From Former Natalee Holloway Murder Suspects Dismissed|url=http://radaronline.com/exclusives/2015/03/dr-phil-natalee-holloway-defamation-lawsuit-dismissed/|accessdate=21 April 2017|work=Radar Staff|publisher=Radar Online, LLC|date=24 March 2015}} ===Britney Spears "intervention" (2008)=== In January 2008, McGraw visited pop star [[Britney Spears]] in her hospital room.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/10/arts/television/10stan.html|title=Further Adventures in America’s Favorite Pastime, 'Addictionology'|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=NY Times|author=Alessandra Stanley | date=January 10, 2008}} The visit by McGraw drew criticism from the Spears family and from mental health professionals. The visit appeared to be part of an attempt at getting Spears and her parents to take part in an "intervention" on the ''Dr. Phil'' television show.{{cite news|url=http://www.showbuzz.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/07/people_hot_water/main3681931.shtml|title=Britney In Desert, Dr. Phil Show A No-Go|accessdate=January 12, 2008|publisher=CBS|author=CBS Interactive Inc.|date=January 7, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110092933/http://www.showbuzz.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/01/07/people_hot_water/main3681931.shtml|archivedate=January 10, 2008|df=mdy-all}} Immediately after the visit, McGraw issued public statements{{cite web|url=http://www.etonline.com/news/2008/01/57024/index.html |title=Dr. Phil's Exclusive Statement to ET on Britney |accessdate=January 5, 2008 |publisher=CBS Studios Inc. |year=2008 |author=Anon |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107003706/http://www.etonline.com/news/2008/01/57024/index.html |archivedate=January 7, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.theinsideronline.com/news/2008/01/15019/index.html|title=Dr. Phil's Exclusive Statement to 'The Insider' on Britney|accessdate=January 5, 2008|publisher=CBS Studios Inc.|year=2008|author=Anon|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20080301213624/http://www.theinsideronline.com/news/2008/01/15019/index.html|archivedate=March 1, 2008|df=mdy-all}} about Spears's situation that Spears's family spokeswoman Lou Taylor said violated their family trust in McGraw. "This is another example of a trust being betrayed", Taylor told ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'' co-host [[Meredith Vieira]]. "Rather than helping the family’s situation, the celebrity psychologist caused additional damage", she said.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/22570295/|title=Spears' parents say Dr. Phil violated their trust|accessdate=January 12, 2008|publisher=MSNBC|year=2008|author=Mike Celizic}} Several mental health care professionals criticized McGraw for his actions, but fellow television psychologist [[Joyce Brothers]] defended McGraw.{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jCi9IipOCulyedxVUddN3vckzqXgD8U1N89G0 |title=Dr. Phil Criticized for Britney Brouhaha |accessdate=January 12, 2008 |agency=Associated Press |year=2008 |author=John Rogers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080112113721/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jCi9IipOCulyedxVUddN3vckzqXgD8U1N89G0 |archivedate=January 12, 2008 }} It was reported that a psychologist filed a complaint with the California Board of Psychology (BOP), alleging that McGraw had practiced psychology without a license and had violated doctor-patient privilege by discussing Spears's case with the media.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,323744,00.html|title=Dr. Phil Reportedly Under Investigation in Britney Drama|accessdate=September 18, 2009|publisher=FOXNews.com | date=January 18, 2008}} A copy of the complaint appeared in the media, but there is no way to verify whether or not it was actually submitted to the BOP. The BOP does not disclose that information unless an investigation is opened.{{cite web|url=http://everydaypsychology.com/2008/01/is-dr-phil-actually-psychologist.html |title=Is Dr. Phil actually a Psychologist? | at |publisher=Everydaypsychology.com |date=January 29, 2008 |accessdate=December 31, 2010}} Martin Greenberg, a former BOP President, said on the ''Today Show'' that this incident was not a matter that the law covers or would be concerned about. ===Polk County, Florida, controversy (2008)=== On April 13, 2008, a producer for the ''Dr. Phil'' show secured $30,000 bail for the ringleader of a group of eight teenage girls who viciously beat another girl and videotaped the attack.{{cite web | url=http://www.theweekdaily.com/arts_leisure/people_gossip/39033/did_dr_phil_go_too_far.html | title=Did Dr. Phil go too far? | date=April 14, 2008 | accessdate=April 14, 2008 | publisher=[[The Week]] }} The teen had been booked at the [[Polk County, Florida]], jail on charges that included kidnapping and assault. Producers of the ''Dr. Phil ''show had made plans to tape a one-hour show devoted to the incident and had sent a production assistant to Orlando to help book guests for the show, but when news broke that the ''Dr. Phil'' show producer had posted bail for the teen, the outcry caused the show to cancel their plans. "In this case certain staffers went beyond our guidelines," said Theresa Corigliano, spokesperson for the ''Dr. Phil'' show. "We have decided not to go forward with the story as our guidelines have been compromised."{{cite web|url=http://newsfeedresearcher.com/data/articles_e16/ide2008.04.15.01.35.12.html#hdng0 |title=Dr. Phil Staffers Bail on Show Guidelines |date=April 15, 2008 |accessdate=April 16, 2008 |publisher=NewsFeed Researcher }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{Full citation needed|date=August 2008}} ===Riccio lawsuit (2008)=== McGraw was sued by [[Thomas Riccio (auction owner)|Thomas Riccio]], the memorabilia collector responsible for taping the Las Vegas robbery that led to [[O. J. Simpson]]'s being convicted. Riccio sued McGraw in Los Angeles Superior Court for defamation, fraud, intentional infliction of emotional distress and false light for what Riccio claims to have been deceitful editing of the ''Dr. Phil Show'' on which he appeared in early October 2008.[http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5guIBXhZup6TwEB55A-UYPpumEMxAD93V8NEG0 Simpson trial witness sues Dr. Phil for defamation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024133320/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5guIBXhZup6TwEB55A-UYPpumEMxAD93V8NEG0 |date=October 24, 2008 }} The claims of defamation, intentional infliction of emotional distress and false light were dismissed, with the judge finding that it was protected speech under the First Amendment.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/entertainment/celebrity/Judge-Dismisses-Simpson-Witness-Claim-Against-Dr-Phil.html|title=Judge Backs Dr. Phil in Defamation Lawsuit|work=NBC Southern California|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en}} == Approach to psychology == [[File:PhilMcGrawHWOFMay2013.jpg|thumb|McGraw in May 2013]] McGraw's advice and methods have drawn criticism from some fellow psychotherapists as well as from some laymen. McGraw's critics regard advice given by him to be at best simplistic, and at worst, ineffective.{{cite book |last= Salerno|first= Steve|title= SHAM; How the Self-Help Movement Made America Helpless|year= 2005|publisher= Crown Publishers|isbn= 1-4000-5409-5}} The [[National Alliance on Mental Illness]] called McGraw's conduct in one episode of his television show "unethical" and "incredibly irresponsible".{{cite news |last=de Moraes |first=Lisa |title=On Dr. Phil, a Dose of Bad Medicine? |work=Washington Post | date=1 September 2004 |p=C7 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A63905-2004Sep30.html | access-date=4 August 2017}} McGraw said in a 2001 South Florida newspaper interview that he never liked traditional one-on-one counseling, and that "I'm not the Hush-Puppies, pipe and 'Let's talk about your mother' kind of psychologist."Lavin, Cheryl. "Dr. Tell it Like it Is." ''South Florida Sun Sentinel'', July 3, 2001, Page 1E ==Charitable foundation== McGraw announced the formation of the Dr. Phil Foundation, which raises funds to fight childhood [[obesity]], on October 22, 2003. The Foundation also supports charitable organizations that help address the emotional, spiritual, and monetary needs of children and families.{{cite web|author=Dr. Phil Foundation |url=http://drphilfoundation.org/docs/2003-10-22.pdf |format=PDF |title=Dr. Phil McGraw announces the formation of the Dr. Phil Foundation |publisher=Dr. Phil Foundation |accessdate=October 19, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430192617/http://drphilfoundation.org/docs/2003-10-22.pdf |archivedate=April 30, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} ==Personal life== [[File:PhilRobinMcGrawHWOFMay2013.jpg|thumb|right|McGraw with wife Robin in May 2013]] McGraw married his first wife, an ex-cheerleader and homecoming queen named Debbie Higgins McCall, in 1970, when he was 20 years old. According to her, McGraw was domineering and would not allow her to participate in the family business. She claimed that she was confined to domestic duties, which included lifting weights to improve her bustline.{{cite web|url=http://media.www.nineronline.com/media/storage/paper971/news/2002/10/15/TheDailyExtra/ExWife.Talks.About.Her.Years.With.Dr.Phil-2004477.shtml |title=Ex-wife talks about her years with Dr. Phil |accessdate=July 25, 2008 |publisher=Knight Ridder Newspaper |year=2002 |author=Lisa Gutierrez |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725065222/http://media.www.nineronline.com/media/storage/paper971/news/2002/10/15/TheDailyExtra/ExWife.Talks.About.Her.Years.With.Dr.Phil-2004477.shtml |archivedate=July 25, 2008 }} During the process of annulling the marriage in 1973, McGraw began dating Robin Jo Jameson (born December 28, 1953), whom he married in 1976.{{cite web|url=http://www.sophiadembling.com/2008/07/dr-phil-divorce.html|title=Dr. Phil Divorce?|accessdate=January 27, 2009|publisher=Sophia Dembling|year=2008|author=Sophia Dembling|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623025515/http://www.sophiadembling.com/2008/07/dr-phil-divorce.html|archive-date=June 23, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The couple had two children, Jay, born in 1979, and Jordan, born 1986.{{cite web|url=http://www.goodhousekeeping.com/family/marriage-sex/dr-phil-marriage-makeover|title=Dr. Phil & Robin's Do-It-Yourself Marriage Makeover|accessdate=January 25, 2008|publisher=Hearst Communications, Inc.|year=2002|author=Kate Coyne}} McGraw's son, [[Jay McGraw]], has partially followed in his father's footsteps, publishing books aimed at teenagers based on McGraw's books and working for Stage 29. Jay McGraw became engaged to [[Nicole, Erica and Jaclyn Dahm|Erica Dahm]], one of the famous Playboy Playmate triplets.{{cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Dr-Phil-s-Son-Engaged-to-Triplet-Playboy-Playmate-7413.shtml|title=Dr. Phil’s Son Engaged to Triplet Playboy Playmate|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Softpedia|year=2005|author=Entertainment News Staff|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228230012/http://news.softpedia.com/news/Dr-Phil-s-Son-Engaged-to-Triplet-Playboy-Playmate-7413.shtml|archivedate=February 28, 2008|df=mdy-all}} The elder McGraw was best man at his son's wedding, despite the fact that he is vocally against pornography, which was held at his home in Beverly Hills.{{cite web|url=http://www.drphil.com/shows/page/jayericawedding/|title=Jay & Erica's Wedding|accessdate=January 17, 2008|publisher=Peteski Production, Inc.|year=2006|author=Anon}} McGraw is also a private pilot, with an instrument rating, flying single engine airplanes.{{cite web|url=https://amsrvs.registry.faa.gov/airmeninquiry/Detail.aspx?uniqid=A1250217&certNum=1|title=FAA Registry - Airmen - AirmenInquiry - Last Resort|publisher=}} McGraw has identified himself as a [[Christian]].[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0512/06/lkl.01.html Interview with Dr. Phil McGraw. CNN.] I believe that it’s each to his own. I mean, it’s Christmas in my house. You know, we’re a Christian home and raising a Christian family. For those who haven’t been, do what works for you. I think you got to all get along On 21 October 2017 he was threatened with lawsuit when he accidentally hit a skateboarder with his [[Mercedes-Benz]].{{cite web |url=https://www.eonline.com/news/888597/dr-phil-accidentally-hits-skateboarding-bodybuilder-with-car |title=Dr. Phil Accidentally Hits Skateboarding Bodybuilder With Car |last=Heller |first=Corinne |date=22 October 2017 |access-date=11 June 2018 |work=[[E! Online]] |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]}}{{cite news |last=Sprunk |first=Cara |title=Dr. Phil hit skateboarder with car, is now being threatened with lawsuit: report |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/tv/celebrity/dr-phil-hit-skateboarder-with-car-is-now-being-threatened-with-lawsuit-report/ar-AAtRI0G |date=22 October 2017 |access-date=11 June 2018 |work=[[MSN Entertainment]]}} ==Selected works by Phil McGraw== {{refbegin|30em}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=Life Strategies: Doing What Works, Doing What Matters |publisher=Hyperion Books |location=New York |year=1999 |isbn=0-7868-8459-2}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=The Relationship Rescue Workbook |publisher=Hyperion |location=New York |year= 2000 |isbn=0-7868-8604-8}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C.|title=Relationship Rescue |publisher=Hyperion |location=New York |year=2000 |isbn=0-7868-8598-X}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=The Life Strategies Self-Discovery Journal: Finding What Matters Most for You |publisher=Hyperion |location=New York |year=2001 |isbn=0-7868-8743-5}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. Self Matters Companion: Helping You Create Your Life from the Inside Out |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |year=2003 |isbn=0-7432-2424-8}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=The Ultimate Weight Solution: The 7 Keys to Weight Loss Freedom |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |year=2003 |isbn=0-7432-3674-2}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=The Ultimate Weight Phenomenal Family |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |year=2005 |isbn=0-7432-7377-X}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=The Family First Workbook: Specific Tools, Strategies, and Skills for Creating a Phenomenal Family |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |year=2005|isbn=0-7432-8073-3}} *{{cite book |author=McGraw, Phillip C. |title=Love Smart: Find the One You Want—Fix the One You Got |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |year=2006|isbn=0-7432-9243-X}} {{refend}} ==Filmography== {{BLP unsourced section|date=January 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
